Tofu Stir-fry with Fresh Vegetables

Jump to Recipe

Are you looking for a quick and healthy meal that’s packed with flavor? Look no further than this vibrant Tofu Stir-fry with Fresh Vegetables! Tofu is not only a fantastic source of plant-based protein, but it also absorbs the delicious flavors of the ingredients around it, making it a versatile choice for any stir-fry dish. In this recipe, we combine firm tofu with a colorful medley of bell peppers, crisp broccoli, and sweet carrots, all tossed in a savory soy sauce that brings everything together beautifully. Whether you’re a seasoned vegetarian or simply wanting to add more veggies to your diet, this dish is sure to satisfy your taste buds while providing a nutritious punch. Join us as we explore how to create this delightful stir-fry in your own kitchen, complete with tips for perfecting your tofu and ensuring your vegetables retain their crunch!

Ingredients

firm tofu

To achieve a firmer texture, press the tofu for at least 30 minutes to remove excess moisture. If you can't find firm tofu, you can use extra-firm tofu for a denser texture, or silken tofu for a softer dish, but adjust cooking times accordingly. Marinating the tofu in soy sauce or your favorite seasoning for 15-30 minutes before cooking can enhance its flavor.

bell peppers (mixed colors)

Choose a variety of colors for a vibrant dish; red, yellow, and green peppers each offer different flavor profiles. You can substitute bell peppers with other crunchy vegetables like snap peas or zucchini. To enhance their sweetness, consider roasting them briefly before adding to the stir-fry.

broccoli florets

For the best texture, cut the broccoli into small, uniform florets to ensure even cooking. If fresh broccoli isn't available, you can use frozen broccoli; just add it towards the end of cooking to avoid overcooking. Blanching the broccoli briefly in boiling water before stir-frying can help retain its bright color and crunch.

carrots (sliced)

Slice carrots thinly to ensure they cook quickly and evenly. If you prefer a sweeter flavor, you can use baby carrots or even substitute with parsnips. Adding a pinch of sugar or honey during cooking can enhance their natural sweetness.

soy sauce

For a gluten-free option, use tamari instead of regular soy sauce. You can also experiment with low-sodium soy sauce to reduce salt content or use coconut aminos for a sweeter, milder flavor.

garlic (minced)

Fresh garlic is ideal; however, you can substitute with garlic powder (1/8 tsp per clove) if fresh isn't available. To enhance the garlic flavor, sauté it gently without burning, as burnt garlic can turn bitter.

olive oil

While olive oil works well, you can also use sesame oil for a more authentic Asian flavor or avocado oil for high-heat cooking. If using sesame oil, consider using it in combination with another oil, as it has a lower smoke point.

ginger (minced)

Fresh ginger adds a zesty kick; however, you can substitute with ground ginger (1/4 tsp per inch of fresh ginger). To maximize flavor, use a microplane to finely mince the ginger, allowing it to release more essential oils.

green onions (sliced)

Green onions add a fresh crunch; if unavailable, you can substitute with chives or shallots. For added flavor, consider sautéing them briefly at the end to enhance their sweetness.

sesame seeds (optional)

Toasting the sesame seeds before adding them to the dish will bring out their nutty flavor. You can also substitute with chopped nuts like cashews or peanuts for added crunch.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Press and Prepare Tofu

    To begin, take your 14 oz of firm tofu and wrap it in a clean kitchen towel or paper towels. Place a heavy object, like a skillet or a few cans, on top to press down and remove excess water. Let it sit for at least 15-20 minutes. Once pressed, cut the tofu into bite-sized cubes.

  • Step 2: Heat Oil and Sauté Aromatics

    In a large non-stick pan or wok, heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil over medium-high heat. When the oil is hot (you'll see it shimmer), add 2 cloves of minced garlic and 1 inch of minced ginger. Sauté them for about 1 minute until fragrant, making sure they don't burn.

  • Step 3: Cook Tofu Until Golden Brown

    Add the cubed tofu to the pan. Allow it to cook undisturbed for about 5 minutes, then gently turn the cubes to brown all sides evenly. This should take about 5-7 minutes total. The goal is to achieve a nice golden crust on the tofu, which adds flavor and texture.

  • Step 4: Add Vegetables

    Now it's time to incorporate the veggies! Add 2 sliced bell peppers (mixed colors), 1 cup of broccoli florets, and 1 cup of sliced carrots to the pan. Stir-fry the mixture for 5-7 minutes. The vegetables should be tender but still crisp (al dente).

  • Step 5: Add Soy Sauce and Toss

    Pour 3 tablespoons of soy sauce over the tofu and vegetables. Toss everything together gently to ensure the soy sauce coats all the ingredients evenly. Cook for an additional 2 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.

  • Step 6: Garnish and Serve

    Remove the stir-fry from heat. Garnish with 2 sliced green onions and, if desired, 1 tablespoon of sesame seeds for added flavor and crunch. Serve hot, either on its own or over steamed rice or noodles.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I properly press tofu to remove excess water?

To press tofu, wrap it in a clean kitchen towel or paper towels, then place a heavy object (like a cast iron skillet or a few cans) on top for about 15-30 minutes. This helps to extract moisture, making the tofu firmer and better at absorbing flavors.

What is the best way to cut vegetables for stir-frying?

For stir-frying, aim for uniform sizes to ensure even cooking. Cut bell peppers into strips, carrots into thin slices or matchsticks, and broccoli into small florets. This helps all the ingredients cook at the same rate.

How can I tell when my tofu is cooked?

Cook the tofu until it is golden brown and crispy on the outside. This usually takes about 5-7 minutes over medium-high heat. The texture should be firm and slightly chewy.

What should I do if my vegetables start to burn while stir-frying?

If your vegetables are burning, lower the heat slightly and add a splash of water or broth to the pan. This will create steam and help cook the vegetables without burning.

How do I know when my vegetables are done cooking in a stir-fry?

Vegetables should be tender-crisp, meaning they are cooked through but still have some bite. This usually takes about 5-7 minutes in a hot pan. You can taste a piece to check for doneness.

Is it safe to use a non-stick pan for stir-frying?

Yes, a non-stick pan is safe for stir-frying and can make cooking easier, especially for beginners. Just make sure to use utensils that won't scratch the surface.

Can I substitute other sauces for soy sauce?

Absolutely! You can use tamari (gluten-free soy sauce), coconut aminos, or even a splash of teriyaki sauce for a different flavor. Adjust the quantity to taste.

What is the purpose of garnishing with green onions and sesame seeds?

Garnishing with green onions and sesame seeds adds flavor, crunch, and visual appeal to your dish. It's an easy way to elevate your meal!

How can I ensure my tofu stir-fry is flavorful?

Marinate your tofu in soy sauce, garlic, and ginger for 15-30 minutes before cooking. This infuses flavor and enhances the overall taste of your stir-fry.

How do I clean my cutting board and knife properly after using them?

Wash your cutting board and knife with hot soapy water after each use, especially if you've cut raw vegetables or protein. For wooden cutting boards, apply mineral oil occasionally to keep them in good condition.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This dish is naturally vegan and gluten-free if you use a gluten-free soy sauce alternative, such as tamari. For those following a low-carb diet, you could serve the stir-fry over spiralized zucchini or cauliflower rice instead of traditional grains.

Pairings

For a delightful pairing, serve the Tofu Stir-fry with a side of steamed jasmine rice or quinoa to absorb the flavors. You can also complement the dish with a light protein like grilled chicken or shrimp for non-vegetarians. For beverages, consider a chilled jasmine tea or a light, crisp white wine such as Sauvignon Blanc that won't overpower the dish.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the stir-fry in a large, shallow bowl to showcase the vibrant colors of the vegetables. Garnish with additional green onions and a sprinkle of sesame seeds for added texture and visual appeal. Offer lime wedges on the side for a zesty finish, and consider adding a side of pickled vegetables for a tangy contrast. For a casual gathering, you can serve this dish family-style, allowing guests to help themselves.

Tofu Stir-fry with Fresh Vegetables

25 min
$8
300 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 2

Allergens:

Soy

Dietary Tags:

VegetarianGluten-Free

Cuisine:

AsianAmerican

Course:

Main CourseVegetarian Dish

Tags:

EasyQuickHealthyVegetarian

Description

A colorful and nutritious stir-fry loaded with fresh vegetables and protein-packed tofu, perfect for a quick meal.

Ingredients

  • firm tofu: 14 oz
  • bell peppers (mixed colors): 2
  • broccoli florets: 1 cup
  • carrots (sliced): 1 cup
  • soy sauce: 3 tbsp
  • garlic (minced): 2 cloves
  • olive oil: 2 tbsp
  • ginger (minced): 1 inch
  • green onions (sliced): 2
  • sesame seeds (optional): 1 tbsp
